p: The earliest description of human death associated with vampire bat attacks comes from the time of the Spanish conquest of the Americas in the 16th century [ 7]. Rabies virus transmission from vampire bats to cattle has been recognized for over one hundred years [ 8, 9] and continues to be a major burden to the livestock industry [ 10]. The first documented outbreak of human rabies of vampire bat origin occurred in Trinidad in 1927 [ 11, 12]. These outbreaks have continued to the present day and are a challenge to both the veterinary and human health agencies, which face sudden outbreaks of rabies in livestock or human populations. Such events often occur in remote regions where access to healthcare is restricted [ 13].
